Comments_List: I learned basically everything I know about multibariable calculus.

Learn, conceptually, the principals of multi variable calculus. It provides a new perspective when looking at the world because of the real-life application of these concepts. Mainly physic based applications, though.
Organization was not great, but you learn a lot

The greatest weakness of this course was certainly its structure. Way too many topics were covered and I believe that students had little time to dissect the entire material in such a small amount of time. The level of teaching offered by the various instructors  was very unbalanced and its a shame that students can not select themselves the instructor that they want instead of being randomly paired up with a professor. I felt like the homework did not prepare me well enough for the tests and hope that in the future the psets will be changed so that they better represent the exercises that are found in tests. Finally, even though it can be argued that we had enough practice for exam stile questions provided by the course's director, they were most of the times miles harder than the ones found in the actual tests and did not include any kind of explanation on the solutions.
Sometimes class was confusing. Otherwise no real complaints. Review sessions were immensely helpful.

Strengths: Great content, if taught properly. All the resources are available for students to succeed (review sessions, lots of peer tutors, office hours, etc.)

Weaknesses: Not enough focus on conceptual understand of the material. Testing on concepts was present but very surface level. I want to delve more into the theory behind the math we learn.
Also, heavy weighting on the tests makes taking those stressful.
This course is required for the completion of many STEM majors. If it were not a necessity I would not be likely to recommend it.
Course gives a good understanding of multivariable
If you are interested in math, then take it
No I would not recommend it. Unfortunately it is a prerequisite for most STEM majors at Yale so the hard truth is that most students do not have the option of not taking the course.
Yes but only if they need to take it as a prerequisite or for a major. Not a class just for fun.
Yes I would. This course is extremely satisfying to finish and content wise, was extremely interesting.
